instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.USB_TPAD_P: What is USB_TPAD_P? USB_TPAD_P is the positive signal in a USB data signal transferring keyboard & trackpad use to the CPU from the trackpad. .
definitions.USB_TPAD_N: What is USB_TPAD_N? USB_TPAD_N is the positive signal in a USB data signal transferring keyboard & trackpad use to the CPU from the trackpad. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
All power rails seem to be there but it doesnt recognise the keyboard and trackpad in OSX only in EFI.

Hate these sorta issues. Board has been tested in a know good shell

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: Firstly inspect all SPI lines to the connector, or just diode mode all pins while you are at it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
I really need to get a bench meter with diode mode dont i? :confused:

Using a vintage fluke 8840A at the moment and hate handheld multimeters.
Got out my handheld meter 

1,3,5,7,9,11,13 OL

15,17,31,33,39,47,51,52,40,34,34,30,24,18,16,50,49 0 because GND

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: I doubt pin 1 is OL as it should connect to PPBUS. F4800 dead? Also buy a multimeter these readings look all weird. Any $5 one will do better than this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
I can remeasure if you like duke but i should probably recharge the battery of my Agilent <CHIP>U1512B</CHIP>. Will remeasure later, i think its one of the rails that starts low and then quickly rises to OL.

Im confused, are you suggesting my top end Agilent multimeter is not up to standards?

Other than some very negligible difference i had it side to side with a working board when i took the measurements and didnt see anything wrong with the value. 
I also inspected the SPI lines, all traces and resistors are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: I had this shit yesterday. I just remapped the trackpad/keyboard. . All was ok again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
Did it show as a device? i get the bluetooth keyboard assistant pop up. Ive also tried it on a different SSD. 

Ive done all the other stuff like PRAM reset and reflash the bios

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
There was no activity for keyboard or trackpad in OSX. I didn't bother testing too much as figured it was trackpad related,since logic worked perfect in known good 2015 top case.

I might have just got lucky. 

Do you have a pre-programmed trackpad in stock ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: the trackpad is confirmed working (i always seem to have more than 1 4924 system in stock that i get to use as a testing shell.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: Looking at your measurements "<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> OL" just makes no sense. I cannot trust any of those measurements.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
No Title

Had a brainfart.
Ignore old measurements. New measurements here, compared to two good boards. Cant see anything suspect, but the second good board seems a bit our of whack. (second good board has some corrosion on its trackpad connector though)
Measurements uploaded as a picture to keep the formatting :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: Can you measure <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> with trackpad connected? If they are ok then I suspect crap under the connector, or bad connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message:
All voltages you said are present and healthy with the tpad connected.
Removed the connector, no crap under it, connector replaced, no improvement, I think im done wasting time on this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> keyboard and trackpad only work in EFi
threads.message: Yeah, SPI goes straight into the CPU. I have a few boards here that I can't get the trackpad to work. I assume the CPU has a dead SPI line.
